items.content_html:
Fixes #9732

This originally said the fill() was filling with random values, but what they mean is "an arbitrary value I chose".
This makes it clear that the array is populated with the specified value.
items.title: Array.fill() does not populate with random values

items.content_html:
Summary

Rewritten some sentences and replaced pronouns like 'it' to improve the clarity of the content. Hopefully, the technical accuracy of the page is still intact after the changes.

There is scope to improve the content further (like more examples can be added and some sections can be rewritten). I can take that up if I can work with a subject matter expert to resolve the gaps.

Motivation

Edited this page as part of "Writing Day" during the Write the Docs Prague 2021 conference: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Vary
items.title: Edits and rewrites to improve clarity

items.content_html:
Summary

This change removes the mention of String.replace in the JS doc for Array

Motivation

The discussion of array creation from RegExp in the Array doc mentions that arrays might be returned from String.replace. But String.replace returns a string, instead of an array. Although a string is an array like object, it's technically very different from the array that is being discussed in this particular context:

This array has properties and elements which provide information about the match.

Supporting details

Related issues

items.title: Fix Array JS doc: remove String.replace from RegExp discussion

items.content_html: This PR unlinks the BCD from the FileSystemFlags dictionary to follow along with its removal in BCD, see mdn/browser-compat-data#12766.
items.title: Unlink BCD from FileSystemFlags dictionary

items.content_html: This PR removes the documentation for the EffectTiming API to go along with its removal in BCD, see mdn/browser-compat-data#12765. Additionally, this PR cleans up the remnants of the KeyframeEffectOptions dictionary.
items.title: Remove EffectTiming and KeyframeEffectOptions from MDN

items.content_html:
This PR is a proof-of-concept to show what it would look like if we were to separate the pages for methods in both WebGL 1 and 2 into their own pages, to go along with updates in BCD (see mdn/browser-compat-data#12103). This PR demonstrates the concept using the bufferData method.

CC @foolip @Elchi3
items.title: Separate documentation for WebGL 1 and 2 methods/properties

items.title: Add an example using the second parameter

items.content_html:
This updates the perspective property and perspective() function to
reflect some existing errors (regarding negative values) and some new
CSS working group resolutions that have at this point all shipped in at
least one of Firefox or Chrome (and which I think are all likely to ship
in the other soon, and hopefully in Safari as well):

  • w3c/csswg-drafts#413 resolved that 0 is
    allowed in both the property and the function, but values of both that
    are less than 1px are clamped to 1px.

  • w3c/csswg-drafts#6488 added the none value
    to the perspective() function; it was already a value of the
    perspective property.

It also adds some clarification about what large/small/none values mean.

Supporting details

  • implementing perspective(none): Mozilla bug 1725207, Chromium bug 1253596, WebKit bug 231361
  • clamping of perspective less than 1px: Chromium code change, Chromium announcement, Mozilla bug

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error
items.title: Updates to CSS perspective property and perspective() function.

❓ Why?
Because. That's why!
And, because it's what we do.

items.title: A11Y: Move to Markdown (take 2)

items.content_html:
Summary

Fix the note in the Meaning column for character ^ which says:

This character has a different meaning when it appears at the start of a group.

to say

This character has a different meaning when it appears at the start of a range.

Motivation

I am unable to find any difference in meaning when ^ is used in a group,
at the start or otherwise. It does differ when used in a range.

Supporting details

I am unable to find anything in ECMA 262 22.2 RegExp (Regular Expression) Objects (particularly 22.2.2.6 Assertion) which indicates that the behavior of ^ differs inside and outside a group.

console.assert(/^H/.test('Hi') === /(^H)/.test('Hi'));
console.assert(/^H/.test('hi') === /(^H)/.test('hi'));

I suspect this note is referring to the different behavior when used in a
CharacterClass, referred to as a range elsewhere in the docs, where it denotes inverting the class/range. This is also discussed in the "Different meaning of '?!' combination usage in Assertions and Ranges" section of the same file.

Related issues

Metadata

  • Adds a new document
  • Rewrites (or significantly expands) a document
  • Fixes a typo, bug, or other error

Thanks for considering,
Kevin
items.title: RegExp Assertions: fix note about ^ in group
